description.text:
I designed these parts based on the following sensor:
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Funssor-3D-printer-filament-sensor-with-calble-break-detection-switch-PLA-ABS-broken-material-to-suspend/32809590044.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.5lYblp

This sensor is compatible with my MKS TFT32 touchscreen so I modeled my own case and mount for my printer. I used as reference the model presented on the link shown above.

You basically put the sensor on the bottom part and then you close with the upper part. You can tighten by using M3 screws and nuts. I made slots so that the sensor can be positioned with respect to the filament extruder. I positioned my own so that it stays just below the extruder.

There might be one issue which is to be able to insert the filament through the holes. It needs some practice to pass it through.

title: Tronxy P802MA Anti Z Wobble Caps

description.text:
Hi, I have made these simple caps to stop the Z Wobble they work really well on my machine. They where trial and error getting them just right so as to stop the wobble but not to be to tight to stop the rods spinning, Bear this in mind when you install them and check to make sure the rods still spin ok. I have left holes in the to for spraying oil into them.

*ADDED A Z CAP HOLDER**

I have added a Z Cap Holder as I have noticed the caps working their way out during prints, the holders basically clip over the top of the caps to secure them.

many thanks,

Chris

Notes:

PLA, took 2 Hours and 6 minutes to print at 1.0 speed at 205 C and 40 C print bed. It is nowhere near perfect, but add and adjust all you like.
Some problems with no support, binding was pretty good! It looks COOL!!!

Fourth Time's the Charm!!!

I designed this in Solid Works 2015, transferred it to Cura, and the first print I did I stopped it at five percent to make sure it fit. After it did not fit, I made the hole a little bigger, and on the second go it was a little big, but I figured after shrinking it would fit snug. The third try was right on the money, except for the dish which had no attachment on the post which left me dish-less with a hairball of plastic. The last was perfect and fit really good and not too tight, and the little bugs are relatively easy to fix. I've had lots fun watching it go round and round looking for signals, and I hope you do to!!!

description.text:
This is a motor mount that I made for my E-flite Whip it. It mounts onto the wing using its screws. It works as a pusher configuration.

To complete this build:

  1. A motor with a .25" diameter
  2. A micro quad prop that fits onto the shaft of the motor ( I used some glue to hold on the prop)
  3. The E-flite motor connector would make it easy to take on and off the motor, or you can just solder the motor onto the flight board.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

10

Notes:

print it on its back

Installation

This mount, mounts to the 2 wing screws, so that it is removable.

Solidworks

The file that I made this in is also attached so that you are able to change the diameter of the motor hole. Right now that diameter is .25" which fits the hobbyzone, eflight, or micro quad motors well with a little sanding.
You can change the hole diameter under cut extrude number 6

comments.text:
I have had the glider for about 3 weeks now and it flies great even without wind (I usually discus launch it and get 4 times around before landing). This morning I put the motor on it and tested it out. the motor I used wasn't off of a rc plane, but off a solar car. the motor is not that powerful and very slow, but it did a great job at extending flight times by a significant amount. I feel that if i were to put on a motor made for a ultra micro (without the gear box) it could sustain itself.
As for the micro fpv, I have not tried that. It doesn't have a port like all of their other fpv ready models, so you would need to solder to the board to power your camera. I think that it would be able to carry the camera, but that would hurt your flight times by a significant amount even with a more powerful motor.
I'll put a link to the Youtube video in the thing details with it flying tomorrow. I am going to look for a more powerful motor in the meantime.
Thanks!

author: SerenceBey

description.text:
This is an hard job, guys!!! I love classic robots and I decided to create a real iconic product as the SPACE FIGHTER of HORIKAWA, very expensive to buy, actually.
Here you have ALL the parts to re-create a Robot Horikawa style, a classic vintage toy from 70's, made in japan.
I reconstructed all the parts optimizing them for 3D printing, to reach the best quality result. All the parts are ready to be printed and well positioned in a flat plane to start immediately with your specific Slicer software.
If you want it in a big size, you should have to separate the parts in a multiple print. The original one was 30 cm tall.
You also need some screw to assemble the body and a little quantity of glue (cianoacrylate) to assemble the arms and the head.
The front doors open, but I still have to make the interior.
All the parts are ready to join and I put all the tollerances you'd need to make it move easily.
Please check the right position for each generating part. I put it in an exploded view to let you understand the best way to print them, almost without supports when possibile.

comments.text: I am new to 3D printing, but have collect several Horikawa classics for decades. My question is this. This should be able for someone to replicate on a Mini, if I split the pieces up for print, right? I have not gotten my mini yet, but, this is one of the first things I'd love to print. Any help or advice would be appreciated.
comments.author: Galacticrichie

comments.text: Hello Anchorage! The pads and cylinders are the bottom of the robot feet. You have to print the legs with no bottom/top (on CURA slicer) and without fill, so you will be able to mount the pad and the wheels with a little iron wire. That's why the cylinders have a hole. The doors are not finished and I still have some work to do, but I don't find the time to do it! Feel free to modify or make better some parts! All the best!

description.text: My spool of filament on my Maker Select (Wanhao clone) likes to come unwound sometimes as the nozzle moves back and forth (it's mounted to my control box). This, I fear, will subsequently lead to the filament tangling and jamming, ruining a print if I'm not there to watch it. So I opened Fusion and created this in a few minutes. Should print fine in any material, and slots into the square hole on the side of the filament mount. The arm goes over the top of the spool so the filament can't fall off the side, and should fit most 1kg spools.

OpenForge
=========
Dungeon corridor tiles designed to be compatible with Dwarven Forge dungeon tiles.
The smooth set can be used for any number of things. Look at the Smooth floor tile set for ideas. There, I've done concrete, ice and dirt. Here I've done concrete.
Compatible tiles/walls in this series are tagged with OpenForge
You can find this set on github
OpenForge Sets
=============
  • Smooth Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc.
  • Smooth Edge Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc. Edge tiles.
  • Stone Tile Series - Stone tiles.
  • Stone Edge Tile Series - Stone edge tiles.
  • Crenelated Tile Series - Crenelated Tiles
  • Crenelated Edge Tile Series - Crenelated edge tiles
  • Tudor Tile Series - Tudor tiles.
  • Tudor Edge Tile Series - Tudor edge tiles.
  • Ruined Series - Ruined stone walls
  • Accessories - Pillars, etc.
  • Non-Series Tiles - Misc tiles, such as the pool
  • Module Specific Tiles - Tiles designed for specific modules.
    • OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our website, at our forums, or on twitter and facebook.

When I started printing the Reuleauxminx that I posted last week, I began running into some issues that I hadn't foreseen. To make the necessary tweaks, I decided to get a normal megaminx working first (simpler external piece geometries = faster prototyping).

Here's the result, a rough but functional megaminx. No center caps, so you'll have to deal with exposed screws unless you remix the design, and the clearances are a bit iffy, so be prepared to sand accordingly. I'll get around to a higher quality version of this later, but I really want a physical reuleauxminx in my hands as soon as possible, so I'm moving on to that.

title: Dante Station - Revisited
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a significant upgrade from Dante Station. I added textures to all the surfaces and separated the model into two parts to facilitate removing the support structure. The detail is scaled for an N scale model railroad.

I started the design with Google Sketchup. It is a great program for architectural modeling. But it looked too perfect for an old building so I used ZBrush to age it a little. Then I exported the design and used MakerWare 2.4 to prepare the file for printing on my Replicator2 with the following settings: Infill = 10%
Layer Height = 0.200
Shells = 1
Feedrate = 40
Travel Feed = 55
Temperature = 220 I used a raft with full support. It took a less than 4 hours to print at a height of 44 mm. If you want to use these settings plus change the support angle (which I found helps with overhangs), then create a new profile using MakerBot PLA Standard and modify the following lines: "doSupport": true,
"supportAngle": 45.0,
"layerHeight": 0.20,
"rapidMoveFeedRateXY": 55,
"extruderTemp0": 220,
"extruderTemp1": 220, [also several other places]
"numberOfShells": 1,
"feedrate": 40, [also several other places] This provides more support for overhangs than the default as well as slowing down the printer so the accuracy and quality is better.

the picture is by jack (thanks Jack)

Hello, this is a STEM Project project I did. I was given a task to design something that can help people, so I did a braille solar system to allow blind people mostly students who want to learn about the solar system.

It successfully printed after 3 tries. The first one I set the printing to small, the second try my computer shut down and the third try worked out I adjust the size about 0.65.

So Good Luck. ^^

description.text:
This is the next step from super square-1's. As well as turning with all the functionality of a super square-1, it also can slide along its vertical axis adding even more to the solve.

I may make a bandaged version that mimics the square-1 even more closely, but right now I don't really feel like it. :P

Print:

  • 1 x Core I
  • 1 x Core II
  • 1 x Tooth
  • 1 x Cap
  • 12 x Edge 1
  • 12 x Edge 2

Assembly

Slide the "tooth" into the core. Slide in all edge pieces into the cores. See pictures for reference. Superglue [yes, I know everyone hates super glue] the "tooth" into the other core. Insert cap. That's it, folks!

Disclaimer

Normal super square-1 stickers SHOULD work, but I'm not certain. The cube has 57mm sides.

6.25.2017 - Uploaded a v2 based on my further implementation. Adds ability to drop the mount and space it off the plate. Added some comments to the SCAD file explaining what the options are.

description.text: The SteelSeries Arctis 7 is probably one of the best wireless headsets on the market right now. But for my ears it was almost impossible to wear for more then a few hours without makng my ears sore. This adapter will allow you to put ear cups from the Sony MDR-RF985(or any approx 100mm diam ear cup) on any of the arctis headset line. Makes the ear cups much deeper and spread the clamping force out a bit more. Easily makes this headset 10x more comfortable, especially if you have big ears.

description.text:
This is a easy to carry spinner fidget toy that takes a complete different spin on spinners. The body is best printed on one of the flat sides. However, I've successfully printed it without rotating the cube body file in Cura. Cube body was printed with 100% infill for maximum weight and all the parts are printed at 25% infill. I designed this with tolerances setup for Polymakers PC-Max in mind. The tolerance are very similar to ColorFab's nGen.

https://youtu.be/a7OPsA8IbbU

title: Dan's Blokify Designs
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
My son, Dan Medwin, used the app Blokify http://blokify.com to design two things. With his permission, I have posted them here. The app is easy to use and will export an STL file for printing. The challenge here was cleaning up the support structure. I decided that the second design actually looked better leaving the support structure in place. If you decide to remove it, be patient and very careful. Design: Dan Medwin
3D Print and Photos: Steve Medwin

These things were designed in Blokify by Dan Medwin. I used MakerWare 2.4 to prepare the file for printing on my Replicator2 with the following settings: Infill = 10%
Layer Height = 0.200
Shells = 1
Feedrate = 40
Travel Feed = 55
Temperature = 220 I used a raft with full support. It took a less than 4 hours to print at a height of 44 mm. If you want to use these settings plus change the support angle (which I found helps with overhangs), then create a new profile using MakerBot PLA Standard and then modify the following lines: "doSupport": true,
"supportAngle": 45.0,
"layerHeight": 0.20,
"rapidMoveFeedRateXY": 55,
"extruderTemp0": 220,
"extruderTemp1": 220, [also several other places]
"numberOfShells": 1,

title: NAS server case for mini ITX motherboard and 5 HDDs / SSDs

description.text:
This is my little project for my ASRock AM1H-ITX home NAS. I use 4 HDDs for RAID and one SSD for Linux.

It uses 4 neodymium magnets (12mm by 2mm) to hold the top and bottom together. The magnet holders are printed separately and glued on with hot glue. This is due to the smallest possible size of this case (just around the mini-ITX mobo specs) so the mobo will not go in if the magnet holders are printed with the bottom.

Two small holes in front are for the power LED and HDD LED, hole in the back is for the power button. Side holes are used to lift it and the side perimeter holes are for the ventilation.

It uses a standard 120mm fan and runs cold most of the time even in summer.

There is no copyright on it, so feel free to contact me for the original DesignSpark Mechanical source files if you want to play around with it and modify in any way.

comments.text: Sure! So the top and bottom are pretty self explanatory. You need one piece of each :) Then you need 8 of the corner pieces with dents for magnets to hold it all together. Then 2 rails for hard drives (up to 5 drives can fit). I put 4 HDDs for RAID5 and 1 bootable SSD in the middle.

author: fr33s7yl0r

title: Adjustable 40mm Fan Mount (Prusa i3)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This allows you to easily add a 40mm fan to a typical Prusa i3. It's based on my original Prusa fan mount, which is curved so that the print does not block the flow of air. It's a very quick print.

I printed with 3 top/bottom layers, two perimeters, and 15% infill. Print the parts, and drill the holes to 3mm. Drill the hole where it mounts to the extruder to 4mm. You may need to file or sand where the two parts join together for a better and smoother fit.   
You can mount the fan on either side of the curved bracket. I have it on the outside in the photo, but I'm probably going to change it to the inside.

description.text:
This buckle,combined with a belt material (I used woven paracord), will produce a nice looking belt with two awesome properties:  
(1) Guaranteed not to set off metal detectors  
(2) Can be used in an emergency to provide almost 50 feet of high-strength para-cord!  
The buckle features a single-print, two-piece design.  The buckle works like any typical one, but prints the part already assembled.  
The design also features a space for personalization (initials, etc).  The version depicted was personalized for my father-- the files provide are the 'vanilla' part.  
STEP file is provided for those who would like to personalize.  
Makes a great father's day present! Enjoy!

(1) Print out. The only support needed is included in the part itself for easy printing  
(2) Remove support piece from underside of tongue.  
(2) Gently rotate tongue to allow it to swivel  
(3) connect a belt-- I used woven para-cord for that aweseome survival touch  
(4) Wear proudly without fear of tripping a metal detector, and with the knowledge that you are also carrying survival equipment in case of emergency!

Could be disposable, or just as easily washed and reused! Simply install between the case and the desired fan. I personally recommend use with high static pressure fans (as opposed to high airflow fans) and with air intake fans (as opposed to ventilation fans).

I use a raspberry pi to run an Arduino uno with cnc shield to run my 40x40mm root2 cnc machine, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2286040.

The raspberry Pi is set to run as a headless computer in Client and AP mode simultaneously and so I can log on to the Pi direct through it's AP.

It's such a nice compact solution that I decided to mount as much as practical directly to the gantry side plate to cut down on stepper motor cables.

The IP address 192.168.2.1 which is the AP IP for VNC Viewer is printed on the top section.
I have also allowed room for an end stop low pass filter as per this guide. https://github.com/gnea/grbl/wiki/Wiring-Limit-Switches
In the bottom section there is cable spaces for 6 end stops, a auto level probe and a soft E-stop.
In the mid section there are cable spaces for four stepper motor cables and a power cable.

A 60mm fan is mounted in the top section to cool the stepper drivers.

All three sections are bolted together with 4 x 40mm shcs and plain nuts. The external mounts are to suit the side plates of the 40x40 root2 cnc.

Printed in PLA with 3 perimeters, 25% infill, and support on the mid section.

title: iPhone 6 Plus Crib Ball Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Two-part swivel mount to position iPhone 6 Plus on the side of a baby crib for use as a baby monitor. Contains a ball and socket joint for flexible swivel positioning.

(UPDATE 9 July 2017: slight revisions to the phone mounting bracket. Thinned the phone clasps to reduce friction to a more manageable level, added two new socket cut-outs to allow horizontal as well as vertical orientation, and slightly increased the socket contact angle with the ball joint.)

Designed to fit a 2.5" (63.5mm) wide crib railing with one flat and one rounded side (as shown in picture), because that's what our crib had. Easily snaps on. Crib rail depth is about 1" (25mm).

The base is big enough that it will also function as a freestanding (tabletop or countertop) swivel mount as long as nothing bumps it.

The ball and socket took a few tries to get the diameters and dimensions just right for appropriate friction, and enable snapping together without breaking the print. YMMV.

author: Lonebusa

description.text:
A coin/token to represent/promote the cryptocurrency, SiaCoin. Can be printed with a single extruder with the logo and name cut out (sunken into the coin) or as a Dual Extruder print with the logo embedded into the coin in a different colour. The outer ring is printed separately and the coin is pressed into that after print (no glue required it is a tight squeeze). I usually use a hammer to get it inside the ring and then to adjust it slightly to get it centred. I would recommend scaling the outer ring up by 1% to make it even easier to get it in.
I have included a file to just print the name and logo if you want to use that anywhere else, but if you just want to print the coin there are two options:
1.Dual Extrusion: Add the two 'DualEx' files to the one print, make sure they are lined up and pick your colours. Then print the outer ring (scale up by 1%) and push coin in the ring.
2.Single Extruder: Print the 'Coin-Sunken-Logo' file and then print the outer ring (scale up by 1%). Push coin into ring.

Both options have the SiaCoin logo on one side and the word Sia (with the logo as the A) on the other side.

title: Micro Adjustable Z End Stop
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is based on my Micro Adjustable Bare Wire Z End Stop, which allows for very precise Z positioning. This variation still supports bare wires, but in the photo you can see I've just superglued a mechanical switch onto the side of it. It snaps onto the smooth rod and tightens into place with an M3 set screw (and trapped nut). The adjustment hardware is hidden by the knob.

Print the parts and use a drill to clean up the holes to 3mm. Melt a nut into the base of the knob, and another nut into the trap that allows it to be fastened to the smooth rod. Melt and glue an M3 screw through the top of the switch holder, then add a spring, and put it through the mounting bracket. Screw the knob into the bottom where the screw is exposed.   
In the photo I use an M3 set screw to hold the piece in place, but it snaps on pretty tightly even without it.

Fashionable, functional, cross pendant I designed to retain my glasses when i'm not driving.
BTW this is the 1st design ive shared online and i look forward to following it up with more of my creations.

Printer:

CTC dual

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

Pendant=50% Oval loop=100%

Notes:

I used PLA, however I would be interested to see this design in other interesting materials/colours.
Supports only required for The cross pendant- the oval loop doesn't require supports!
I believe the best print orientation for the cross pendant is stood up with supports for the arms.
I did use a raft for the cross pendant, however it isn't necessarily required. (the oval loop doesn't require a raft.
Layer cooling fan used for the cross pendant but not required for the oval loop
The oval loop was printed with 100% infill as its too fine to be anything less & the cross pendant was printed with 50% infill (you could print the cross with less or more infill as desired)
I modelled the oval loop to be printed with a .4mm nozzle therefore the nozzle performs 2 passes resulting in a thickness of .8mm x .8mm height (4x .2mm layer height).

Hot water forming the Oval loop

When hot water forming the oval loop DONT use boiling water.
Use a regular hot tap for just a couple of seconds whilst slightly stretching the loop by seperating the 5mm & 3mm tools (this takes up the slack of the temporarily malleable pla loop)- Hold this position with gentle pressure for a couple of seconds so the loop cools into its new defined shape as per images step6, step7 & step8.

title: Nerf Stryfe Anti Jammer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Sock Nerf Guns are ridiculous they Jam ALL the time.. This is NORMALLY because the Dart pops out the top of the mag and OR is so badly aligned with the barrel/ Motors that when pushed forward by the trigger it does not go in but folds up like a banana. Jams are a Huge problem for my Nerf gun because you can't have one hand on the trigger while the other opens the Jam door and un Jams it.... So i made this which you just bolt to the Jam door. This prevents the Darts from popping up AND ensures the are correctly aligned to the barrel.

FYI i dont think you can open the jam door after this mod.

M3 12mm bolts .. should be tapped with M3 Tap

This simple block is a MUST have If you reuse ammo

comments.text: Its modeled after the working Stirling engine in the photo and has all of the heat exchange vents installed. A Stirling engine is powered by the exchange of heat between the two air locks, which when the motor is primed by rotating it once it will start pumping and will continue to do so until the flame goes out. As long as it is printed with a high temperature rated and reliable filament it will work, obviously not as well as a metal one but you should get a few revolutions at least.

description.text: E7A Wedgetail Early Warning Aircraft Model. It is split into pieces with alignment keys / slots for easy printing and reconstruction. The orientation and scale how you print I will leave to the user as every printer is different. See my printer settings for what I did. The completed model is tail heavy but a tai stand would be easy to design.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

You will need to scale down to 20% for my Wanhao. I orientated all the parts so they stand vertically except for the radar which you can decide on the best way to print.
Depending on your printer you will need to customise some supports. The undercarriage is the trickiest part of the model to get right and not break off. Note that the wings have some small non manifold areas that I could not easily repair but it does not change the print.
All the pieces should just slot together. Add glue and you have yourself a E7A Wedgetail Model.

This model was built from a VRML model that I had. I have fixed areas that were too thin to print and obviously split the model into parts for easy printing. I added the slots and keys to make alignment and gluing easy. Have fun and let me know how your build goes.

comments.text: It's so cool that you have done a model of the Wedgetail. I was the lead designer (UG 18!) and technical support liaison to Northrop Grumman for the tooling used to manufacture the radar. Your post brings back a lot of memories. Thank you.

description.text:
artistic license Honda brake lever profile.

It snaps if printed not solid, I haven't actually tried it solid (I did hex 15% fill, 2 wall, and then cut it off and welding it too the aluminium leftover original - it's good enough)

Note: the stl is slightly wrong in size, if lazy, do scale it up by about 4% (top of my head), should be better fit.

I'm not going to print another one to find out if its perfect - the one I have on the bike now should last forever even after an accident, all I have todo is reheat the plastic into position....you can use cokebottle plastic too as a shrink fit at the snapped section.

This is a box headed guy that talks when you pick him up. You can record a new message for the boxman to say and leave him around for your friends to pick up. It is like a piece of you is always there, until somebody else records over you and you are gone. Here is a link to a youtube clip of it saying some nerdy things! http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m-OaE8rOz_o

Make a box-shaped head with some eye-holes and a nose hole for LEDs.  Leave an open space for the mouth, so the speaker has some room to be heard.  Hack a radioshack speaker module to be activated by a photoresister.  Insert the module into the box.  Glue the speaker to the back of the face of the box (it gets great volume this way!).  I cobbled together a 9V power source for the module by stringing together some 3V coin cells.  This project should take you anywhere from 1 to 1000 hours and then PRESTO! The Talker.  
Also, I hooked up the blue LED straight to the tabs on the speaker, so it is responding directly to the vocal output.  The yellow LEDs for the eyes are soldered directly to the Radio Shack sound module and replace a tiny surface mount red LED. They blink on and off as the recorder is playing and also light up when you depress the RECORD button and stay lit until the memory is full or you release the button (about 20 seconds or so).

A pair of spacers for drandolph's "3mm hood and cover" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23386 4.3mm tall, 3mm interior dia, 4mm external dia, with a built-in 6mm dia washer on the machine-ward end. This piece keeps compression on both bolts holding the y-axis rods.

comments.text: Looks cool.  Do you happen to have an example photo of these installed? I just received my derivative of drandolph's hood and cover from the laser cutter. I  have not yet replaced the y-axis rod screws with the longer ones that support the front window.  I didn't want to misalign the rods in the process.
comments.author: andyways

comments.text: I just uploaded a closeup of the part in action.  I'm not at all worried about the original rig-as-designed causing rod-float issues.  These spacers just prevent the exposed bolt head from floating back into the machine, making it harder to put the front cover back on.  Really, at some point, I'll replace these with some spacer sleeve from the hardware store, but this was a quick, easy workaround from available materials.

I have a stupid "L" shaped shower curtain rod in my bathroom that sags due to poor wall mounts. I designed this support to hold up the corner and relieve the stress on the brackets.

You will need:

  • a length of #10 ball chain
  • 2x #10 ball chain end links
  • 1x M4 12mm screw
  • 1x M4 15mm screw
  • 2x M4 nuts

To assemble, put the end links on the ends of the chain and slide into the slots on the mounts. The screw will pass through the holes in the links and attach to the nut on the other side. Do not tighten too much or your part will crack.

comments.text:
OK. Nice job BTW.
So what's probably happened is the slicer has not taken into account the width of the extruder tip (probably 0.4mm) and so the inner sphere diameter needs to be specified as being bigger by 1mm than the actual ball. Then the insert will hopefully not spread when you put the sphere in.
You can tell because the gap(split) should be 2mm across. It looks bigger in the pic.
If that's OK but still doesn't fit, then the same rule for the 22mm outer diameter. In which case you should change it to 21mm instead.

remixed_from.title: dipole antenna center support with so-239 mount and painters pole adapter

title: 3/8" x 24 Threaded Antenna Dipole Pole Mount

description.text:
I was looking for an inexpensive way to mount two antennas horizontally on top of a tall painters pole. This block accepts a 3/8" x 24 hex nut on each side of the mounting hole. I then took a 3/8 x 1-1/4" washer with a hole drilled, sandwiched it between the antenna and the nut, soldered one leg of ladder line to each washer, and then run the line down to my radio.

I used supports generated by Cura (2.4 and 2.6 both did a fine job), but it's a little tricky to pull all the material out of the center hole where the painters pole will go. Be careful not to pull out the threads when removing supports.

The biggest obstacle is printing something strong enough to hold the 10 foot whips I'm trying to mount. I'm using PLA and super-gluing the hex nuts in place, but the plastic just isn't strong enough and has come apart at the layers. I'd recommend printing with something stronger, or maybe trying to strengthen the print with an epoxy coating (assuming it doesn't melt the plastic) or similar.

I haven't measured impedance or done any significant testing yet, so YMMV!

I'm marking this as a "work in progress" as it's not quite ready for the 10' whips I'm throwing at it, but it'll probably work a lot better for shorter/lighter antennas. I've also included a version with rounded edges. I haven't printed this rounded one yet, but it's a little more sleek so I'm throwing it up in case someone wants to try it out.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Layers @ .2 mm, walls @ 1.2mm

Infill:

20% Tetrahedral

Notes:

I used Cura (2.4, 2.6beta) and chose the tetrahedral infill pattern for additional strength. Informal testing shows it's fairly strong (doesn't flex or crush), but my biggest problem is delamination caused by the pressure generated by the whip hanging off the hex nut. I'm going to try oven baking it post-print, or perhaps adding a few % to the build size and then coating the whole thing with epoxy or similar.

description.text:
This is my Chip-E android remix.

I had to redesign the entire body into a cylindrical shape. The assembly steps are essentially the same as the original Chip-E since the body is still sectioned into the same sections.

The main difference is that the lcd panel goes through the tube connecting the droids head and needs to be hot-glued behind the eye-holes.

The arms are designed to swing back and forth as Chip-E dances or walks. You will need two skateboard bearings to attach the arms.

Unfortunately the increase in size of my Chip-Droid has caused it to have a little difficulty with falling over when walking or dancing. I tried printing bigger feet for poor clumsy Chip-Droid, but it didn't seem to help. I might try to modify the code to get him to either move slower or use smaller stepper angles.

Enjoy the Chip-Droid!

print_settings.Notes:: Print with two outlines for maximum strength.

description.text:
~This is a work in progress. I will finish designing the base of the skimmer once I have my pump to work with

CHANGELOG

6/30/17- Finished the lower body, updated the upper neck profile, and resized the parts to fit a 1/8" thick, 6" wide acrylic tube.
6/23/17- Rounded off the bottom of the upper neck for aesthetics.

Seeing that protein skimmers cost so much for an assembly of acrylic tubes and plastic, I figured that it would be possible to make a replica of one for less than half the cost! This skimmer is designed with the pump in the reaction chamber itself, to save space for those with smaller sumps (like mine).

You will need around 18 inches of height in your sump area to comfortably house this skimmer. Aside from the 3D printed parts, you will also need:

-A foot of 6" OD, 1/8" thick acrylic tubing for the walls of the collection cup and lower skimmer body

-A Jebao DC-1200 pump kit. I purchased a replacement pump that comes with a needle wheel impeller and an intake silencer from Fish Street:

http://www.fish-street.com/coral_box_dc_skimmer_pump

-A gasket ring for the upper neck, to seal the connection between it and the collection cup.

-4x M5 nylon thumbscrews for the bottom base. If you can't find any, try printing some out with this:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2175820

Assembly video is coming, once I finish designing this!

Printer:

Tevo Black Widow

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Print with two outlines for maximum strength.

After printing and sanding it to fit snugly, you should coat the parts with sealer to make the print watertight. If using ABS, then you could try to seal it with an acetone vapor bath. I used epoxy to do this with PETG.

comments.text: I have found that the O ring is not even necessary. In my testing, I noticed that the water level does not get up beyond the neck of the skimmer. The foam head will not leak out from the neck either. So long as it fits snugly (but not so much so that it is difficult to take off), it will be a tight enough seal.

description.text:

description.text: I made this for a friend of mine who noticed his Fibaro HC2 was running hot. The grill replaces the side panel on the Fibaro and allows the heat to dissipate adequately to reduce the temperature considerably.

title: Filament Bolt and Nut with dust filter

description.text: Nut and bolt combination to feed 3D filament through the wall of a airtight container. To help keep it airtight, it incorporates a dust filter in the bolt shaft.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

20-40%

Notes:

I printed this at 0.1 layer height and very slow (25mm/s) so that the thread would be rendered nicely. I also had z-hop enabled for 0.2mm. The nut thread has been modified to be 0.2 mm wider than the bolt so it all works nicely. Mine worked perfectly directly from the bed without any cleanup on the thread.
Print them separately as you do not want to enable any supports where the thread is. So, print the nut, lying flat, with no support. The bolt must be printed also laying flat, but with the shaft pointed up, and enable only support (about 20% and lines ) that touches the bed (i.e., no support to touch the thread). Once printed remove the support material from the hole in the bolt, clean the rounded edges (I used very fine waterpaper 2000 grit) and stuff a piece of foam in the hole (white in the photo). The bolt gets mounted on the inside of the box and the nut outside. Push the filament through the foam so, as it is pulled through, it gets cleaned.

I use 2 in each hole. May need to "expand" the bores to make the fit easier.
These work as the magnetic mount to hold the colorizer on top of the extruder.

Minor design flaw (or feature) the mount does not quite fit on my machine (too long)
so I added an extra magnet under the mount and it works great.

Next (optional) print out 4 of the pencap objects. Use these with rubber bands (only need 1 each) to hold the pens in place. You do not needs alot of force, just enough to keep the pen in place.

The tabs on the colorizer do not seem to print very well, but they are good enough. It has to do with the angle, sharpness, and diameter of the tabs. I wanted them small enough that they would not interfere with operations yet big enough to work. They are only 3mm or
less, so do not put too much pressure on them and you will be fine.
I was unable to easily edit the original file, so I hacked this together with tinkercad.

title: IPad Mini 4 Holder Hood combo for Mavic Pro RC

description.text:
DJI Mavic Pro - Holder for IPad Mini 4

Suggest you keep checking back once a week as I will be uploading variations and tweaks regularly as I think of them or if design changes are made !

Updates - See bottom of summary for more details

  • 23/06/2017
    Shade holder mod.
  • 24/06/2017
    V3 Shade holder with side shades
  • 24/06/2017
    Removed the original Hood and added a rear view

Summary of parts

  • Base to hold in Mavic RC
  • Left and Right IPad Mini 4 Holders
  • Sun Shade Holder - Optional
  • Sun Shade - Optional

How to use

Should be pretty obvious, but just in case;.

  1. Slide the Shade Holder into the base (#4) until it slides out of one dovetail into the next. The holder should sit right in the middle of the two dovetails on the base.
  2. Slide the Left IPad holder (#2) into the base(#4).
  3. Slide the IPad into The Left IPad holder (#2).
  4. Slide the Right hand IPad holder (#3) onto the Right of the IPad and into the dovetail on the base (#4)
  5. Clamp the Mavic controller onto number 4 (Base) gently or you may break the Stops built into the Left and Right IPad holders.
  6. Slide in the V1 Shade or V3 with Side shades as required.

If you don't need to use the shade, just skip steps 1 and 6.

Design Notes

I tried to design this to be as modular as possible so it could be broken down into smaller parts for easy transport / packing. Using the Sun Shade and holder is also optional in this way.

The shade was not made too wide or this would inhibit your thumbs from accessing the RC joysticks easily. This may still be an issue for users with smaller hands. I myself have large hands and I don't have this issue.

Think of this as a IPad holding the RC rather than the RC holding the IPad and it will help you get used to the design and how to use it :)

Tips

The screen shots from Simplify3D show the best orientation I found for the parts and the support material for the best quality print.

  • Support material is a MUST where noted on the Simplify3D screen Shots and print should be oriented as shown as per the screen shots or you may get poor fitting dovetails and finish !

Printing Notes

  • PLA was used and tested. ABS or other plastics could be used, but due the shrinkage you may have problems with the dovetails or fitting the parts to the Mavic. You could try to compensate for the shrinkage, but I foresee lots of wasted prints !

To Come

  • I will upload more parts / tweaks as needed (Or as I think of them). I am deciding whether shades for the sides are needed when I go flying this weekend :) Any updates to existing parts or additions will be noted in Updates at the bottom of the summary.

  • I will upload photos in the next few days when I get a chance to takes some.

Updates

  • 23/06/2017
    -Shade Holder V2 uploaded. Removed original.
    Found the Shade holder was too tall and may cause the shade to restrict the view of lower joystick movements. Stick will miss the shade with either holder, just couldn't see the stick in the low position too well. Moved the holder slot down by 5mm. This is V2.

  • 24/06/2017
    V3 Shade holder with side shades added. Not tested as yet.

print_settings.Notes:: OnShape

title: Automatic Pet Feeder With Simple Encoder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
It all started with the simple conclusion that I was really annoyed by my cat Mia walking on my face at 6am every day to get her morning food allowance. My girlfriend and I rescued her from a shelter and the poor thing can't self-manage the amount of food she eats, leading to a slight overweight that we are controlling with a strict diet. Since the total amount of food per day is quite low (45 to 50 grams), the vet suggested we feed her multiple times a day. We settled on 3 times a day which meant we needed to bring out the scales and dose the dry food way too often for my taste. This also meant kitty was hungry very early in the mornings and didn't hesitate to let us know in her own way.

There comes my addiction for Arduino-based devices and 3D printing (y'all know how it goes). The list of parts you will need is as follows:

  • An Arduino-based microcontroller (Arduino Pro Micro in my case)
  • A real-time clock module (DS3231 or similar)
  • A TowerPro MG995 continuous rotation servo motor
  • A standard LED
  • A standard light-dependent resistor (LDR)
  • A couple of resistors (around 10k ohms for the LDR, and around 220 ohms for the LED)
  • Wires
  • Optional: push button

Refer to the images for the wiring. I put the LDR and LED on the same circuit to be able to turn them both on with the same pin. I used some digital pins for power since the Pro Micro doesn't have a lot of 5V power outputs. I added a button for manual activation but that was mainly used during the testing phase and I would maybe keep it for the occasional bug where the device doesn't perform exactly as expected.

One important thing to note is that the servo will draw quite a lot of current and the regulated 5V outputs from the Arduino won't be able to make it turn, it will reset the board. You should really wire the servo Vin input to Vbat or Vraw output on the Arduino (unregulated), and make sure you power your Arduino using 5V (with USB for example).

You then need to glue the "Coupler" printed part with the little adapter that comes with the servo (to put on the servo gear). I used the circular one and glued them with CA glue as seen in the pictures. I originally intended to use the coupler directly on the servo but I didn't quite work, it's much better to use the provided adapter which has teeth to match the servo's gear teeth.

I taped the LED and LDR to the lid with duct tape and did the wiring by soldering the various wires and resistors together like in the schematics, without using a breadboard obviously. Heat shrink or electrical tape around every solder point made sure that no short circuit could happen.

Note that all the parts as available here have been optimized for 0.48mm extrusion width and 0.3mm layer height. Should you wish to print with different settings, I encourage you to create a free account on OnShape and edit the variables at the top of the public document for this project.

To refill the device, no need to unplug anything. Simply lift the lid and put it on the side, taking care not to pull on the wires too much. Take the main body with the "blades" part out of the support, turn the blades so that the slot in the middle is vertical (north-south if you prefer). This should align one of the compartments with the opening on the right (or left depending on how you see it). You then proceed to fill the compartments with the right amount of food (I usually put the device on scales to weigh the precise amount). One compartment on the right stays empty. Then, remove the adapter from the servo, turn it with the orientation matching the slot in the rotating "blades" part (so north-south again) and insert it back. Finally, put the body back on the support, and the lid back on the body.

The device has now been working flawlessly for over a month, although it could probably be improved upon. One thing to note is that my cat is pretty chill with machines, she never tried attacking the thing (yet) but some cats are friggin crazy and this design won't stand a lot of abuse.

EDIT 2017-08-25: updated the microcontroller software with the following changes

  • "Detaching" the servo pin when not in use. If permanently attached, the pin would send electronic noise to the servo and cause audible noise (clicks). This is now fixed.
  • Slightly increased motor rotation speed
  • Tuned LED "on" delay and removed rotation stop delay according to new speed
  • Added failsafe in case of LED failure, to not rotate infinitely

EDIT 2017-09-26: slight speed and LED delay tuning. Note that your servo might perform differently, requiring adapting of these parameters, like explained in the code comments.

Printer:

eMotion Tech MicroDelta Rework

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

You can print all the parts in the same orientation as they are in the STL files. Everything should print without supports but you might want to use a skirt to prevent lifting of the "Blades" and "Support" parts since the area of contact with the bed is small. I designed 2 slots at the base of the "Support" part to allow space for the rubber mat we use. They should print as bridges quite easily.

TIP: print two of the "Coupler" part, and use one to block the hole while refilling the machine, so that no food gets into the center hole.

I would advise you to use black filament for the rotating part since it should block all light coming from the LED during rotation.

Note that all the parts as available here have been optimized for 0.48mm extrusion width and 0.3mm layer height. Should you wish to print with different settings, I encourage you to create a free account on OnShape and edit the variables at the top of the public document for this project.

I already had a bunch of microcontrollers laying around a few other parts like LEDs, light-dependent resistors, a real-time clock module and some breadboard wires. After a few unsuccessful tries for designs based on Auger screws and a not-so-powerful stepper motor (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27854 was the main inspiration), I came to the conclusion that Auger screws are not well suited to this application because dry food often gets stuck and controlling the amount precisely (which was a requirement) is tricky.

I then came across this design by SuperBearFur that struck me with its beautiful simplicity: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:497637

So I designed a first version similar to that one, scaled up and tuned for the exact amount of food needed in this case, and three days' worth of food (10 compartments with one being empty, which amounts to 9 doses at 3 doses a day). I needed it to be higher than the ground in order for the food to fall into the bowl, so I made a stand for it, which also doubled as a container for the electronics, and a spout to clip onto the bowl. I ordered a continuous rotation servo for this since it makes the wiring and Arduino code simpler. Since continuous rotation modified servos have no way of encoding the angle of rotation (only the speed), and the friction of the system was such that rotation speed could not easily be controlled, I had to come up with a solution to precisely encode rotation angle.

Here comes the makeshift encoder part of the project. I figured I could design a bunch of holes the in the rotating part that would act as a shutter for a very simple light detector system. On one side of the shutter, a simple LED, on the other side an LDR which, as the name indicates, changes resistance depending on the amount of light. This way, I can turn on the LED right after the rotation started (allowing for the shutter to first block the light path), and the LDR would then read the light amount continuously until the LED's light is visible, indicating that rotation should stop because alignment is perfect.

comments.text:
Your project is great! Your pictures and thorough explanation of everything is even better. I have NO clue about ANYTHING with switches, wires, or anything to do with curcuits, or anything "electrical." I have to call my neighbour over to do SIMPLE fixes around the house such as replacing a light switch, or electrical outlet :'( It is really unfortunate. Our neighbour has offered to teach me, but I am afraid I'll do it wrong and burn down my house...all b/c my kids wanted a "fun colour" for their light switch, lol.) When it comes to learning how to deal with wires and I am incredibly curious about it, and want to learn so that I can broaden my ideas into reality (I DESPERATELY want to build an indoor water pump fed 'garden tower' of sorts, that can self-water every so often. I have all the ideas, and access to all the materials, but the knowledge just isn't there). The thought of doing it wrong, or worse, having to figure out the logistics of it, terrifies me. I am not the type of person that seems to understand the concepts of circuits either apparently. I can't even figure out my kid's curcuit game for an 8 yr old :'( I am the kind of person that in highschool, my computer teacher told (frequently) to "go for a walk, and don't worry about coming back until next class" when I would (accidentally) shut down the computers, simply doing what everyone else was doing...more than a few times (I had the same teacher 2 yrs in a row, and he basically begged me to NOT take any computer classes the next year, regardless of whom the teacher was. I got a good grade, but I'm certain it was b/c he felt badly for me, not b/c of my computer work!). The math student in me can only find the wrong answer (or incredibly infrequently, the correct answer, by either making 2 mistakes (that I can't find, or understand what or how I did it wrong), or just can't even understand the question, so put an answer down so I didn't loose marks). 2+2 is always 5 in my world. Funny enough, I am now married to a computer and math whiz...but that doesn't help me to have fun and do things like what you have done...even when I have the ideas for it.
My local library has a wonderful tinker lab and a number of extremely helpful staff, so I am fairly confidant that with your info/pics, and their help, I could actually do this. I don't have the skills yet to be able to use TinkerCAD on my own (& won't for a LONG, LONG time), so having someone who is able to do the "hard stuff," so I can continue to learn, and apply these ideas and items to my and my family's life, is VERY much appreciated. So, long rambling story, short, thanks for the way that you have presented this. I really wish more people would present their ideas with as much thought and explanation for others (ESP us 'beginners'), as you have. I loveso many of the ideas on this site, but with few (if any), instructions from many creators, find it very difficult to put the ideas into reality.
Oh, and I wanted to mention, I enjoyed the cat in the video...her face said it all :) Hopefully she has found another "thing to do" that allows you to still get some shut eye, in the early morning, now that you have placated her appetite.
Thanks again.

While there are numerous nifty can holders on Thingiverse, I could not find one that helped insulate my drink and keep my precious Diet Dew colder longer. This functional but plain thing holds a standard 12 oz. soda can (or can of similar diameter) and helps insulate it. After using this one for a couple weeks, it seems to work as well as a foam can coolie at keeping my drinks cold.
Stay thirsty my friends...

If you print this holder with an object infill of 5%, you will create a structurally sound holder with a nice air gap between the inner and outer shells which will insulate your can and help keep your drink colder longer.

title: Spool Rollers for Printrbot Simple Tower

description.text:
These parts press-fit onto the bearings on the tower for the Printrbot Simple.   It accomodates spools from 65mm to 90mm in width.  
Note: It might look like the long rollers are sagging, but they are very rigid!   The slight angle is from the way the tower piece is designed.   At most, there is only a 0.6kg load per roller.
A bench vise is recommended to press the bearings in.  It's a nice tight fit.   Parts print good in PLA.

comments.text: Clever design to make use of the existing bearings. I like it.
comments.author: anoved

comments.text: Have you tried using the Printrbot wood spool on this??   I like this MUCH better than the adjustable solutions - no adjusting needed!!

comments.text: The PB wood spool works great on it!  It's 75mm wide and these rollers will accommodate a 90mm width. Changing spools is really fast.  Glad you like it!

title: EZ-Print 2 inch net pots for hydroponics

description.text: Four variations on 2" hydroponic net pots, optimized for printing with standard settings on a Replicator 2.

My original attempt was not easy to print, which is why I created the versions with support built in. The MakerWare generated support was a mess.  
These net pots should automatically have walls that are two layers thick when printed on a Replicator 2 with standard settings. I've included the scad file so that should be easy to tweak if your printer has a different resolution.  
For the two models with a base support, use a pair of pliers to squeeze the support near the base of the pot and it should snap right off.

title: Tesla / Conventional Hybrid Turbine
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I was inspired by this youtube video : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j7YFd4_woxI

However $500 and 1000$ stepper motors arent all that abundant around where i am to just tear apart and rape (especially since i bet that one worked) However brain power and 3d print plastic are common place items in my home. looking at a few paused places in the movie i extrapolated the number of holes in the center were 48, minus the ones he pegged up. Initially i had designed this just as i seen in the video with a center hub that would need the outer wings pinned on it. i dont try and run all that much huge stuff on my printer, however after looking at all i would have to assemble when it was done and not being sure of a design that could possibly (according to other vids) take the centrifugal force associated with 80,000rpm (i highly doubt this does 80Krpm)

After i decided to abandon the rest of the concepts to do with the hub and independent laminated disc junk i came up with a design that incorporates Mr. Teslonians key feature points which is :

  1. More/Smaller slots in the center (does something probably to do with surface area for the tornado to catch)
  2. Internal Spiral blade system (works like a pseudo rotor-ed turbine)
  3. Spiral on outer discs. (functional value? I just though it looked cool)

it looks to take roughly 4 days to print in fine quality, i personally dont think it will function in less than fine quality either. to print and assemble you need 2 of each of the rotors. Use a Marker to number them trust me it will save you some time. from the bottom up on a 100mm M10 carriage head bolt place a bearing then the lid then a spacer then rotor 1, repeat spacer rotor until you get to the spacer on top of rotor 12 then place your second rotor 1 then washer and so on until you are finished, then take M3 all-thread rod and thread it into the hub holes. your printer may make the holes loose in which case you will need m3 nuts, 4 rods works but all 8 gives you some added centrifugal weight. Zoro Tools on ebay sells this rod the nuts and the washers for pennies on the dollar. i bought 100 sticks for like 10$USD, then after the rotors are assembled place the case over it then the top lid then line up the holes and again thread all thread all the way through the holes. DO NOT SKIP THIS STEP. AND DO NOT REPLACE WITH 3MM SCREWS, because while i highly doubt anyone will ever build this, (I actually hope they dont) the possibility of fracturing a rotor is REAL, if it works even near as good as the youtube video suggests we are talking LETHAL SHRAPNEL. therefor while i realize its a poor excuse for safety the all thread creates a cheap little explosion cage to at least get away if you notice something going bad. All that said.. you've been warned Im not your mom so im so not responsible for you impaling, maiming or otherwise messing yourself off.

While conceptionally this design may function in a manner similar to the one in the youtube video all of the included files are original and My personal works, dont be a jerk and steal my work. by all means print it use it educate in what works and dont but dont get rich off of me, lol, i been seeing alot of this going around. im sure Mr Tesalonian wouldnt mind a kick back to if we are all getting rich....

cleaned out blender file included, however im pretty sure if you scale it at all you will mess it up, none of the bolt holes will line up nor will they fit the specified bolts or bearings. the bearing is a 10x22x7mm 100 if them on ebay is like 9$USD

im printing my first one right now in PLA, but later if it works well at low pressures i will print one in ABS, as ABS is a high impact plastic an should be able to take more of the stress and warp less.

one final note DO NOT PRINT 24 OF THE SAME ROTOR!!! they look the same but they are different in the timing of the bolt holes and air escape holes.

title: Monoprice MP Select Mini V2 Z Axis Adjustable Endstop Internal Mount

description.text:
The original endstop by divide was too tall on my Mini v2, I think the opening on the z axis for the x axis arm isn't as low as the v1. I quickly designed an internal endstop mount that attaches to the bottom of the z axis rods.

Spacer is separate (optional if using even longer m3 adjustment screw, I'm using a 30mm) to make it easier to print/use less material.

You will need the adjustment screw holder from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2217149

Intended for use and installed with https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1775502

Very rough and done quickly to get the Mini working again. Made in Fusion 360, step file included.

November 2017 status update: I finally got a replacement MPSMv2 last month. I will likely be updating this design by the end of the year.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

At least 20%

Holes will need to be reamed to fit rods. Does not need to be a tight fit, but there should not be any play.

Mount is sized to be a press fit for the micro switch, some trimming/sanding may be needed if it's too tight. Because of the spacing, fit and application, screws did not seem necessary, but holes could easily be drilled if desired.

comments.text:
Ok printed and in use. Several things.
There are no holes for the screws, meaning the switch dangles, had to use hot glue to keep it steady.

comments.text:
I did not model any screw holes for a couple reasons. The switch sits against the inside wall of the tower and there wouldn't be any room for the faster. I didn't have any screws that small other than the originals, which were too long, and they nuts wouldn't fit.
It was sized so that the switch would be a press fit in to the mount, but I did use a little mounting putty/Blutak.

description.text:
I've already created a potentiometer knob but it was very basic and now with this new version you can change the diameter of the potentiometer shaft and all the design change with it.

The default dimension of the potentiometer shaft in this design is 6 mm ( I choose this because is very common) but if your potentiometer shaft has a different dimension just look at theese istruction:

ISTRUCTION:

  • SOLIDWORKS:
    1) Open the "Potentiometer Knob.SLDPRT"
    2) Tools --> Equations --> Change the only global variable there is (Look the picture for better understandig)

  • FUSION 360:
    1) Open "Potentiometer KNOB - Fusion v1.f3d"
    2) Modify --> Change parameters --> Change the only user parameter there is to the dimension of your potentiometer shaft

  • YOU DON'T HAVE A CAD SOFTWARE?:
    1) Write me in the comment what is the size of your potentiometer shaft and I will upload a .STL file with the dimension you need as quickly as possible
    2) Easy enough? ;-)

title: Fanmingo Fan Duct for Tevo Tarantula

description.text:
This is a minimal fan duct for the tevo tarantula stock hotend, it's based loosely around the one found on the Prusa i3. It has been designed to be as minimalistic as possible, whilst still remaining sturdy, allowing an unfettered view of your hotend and has provided cooling that has been on par or better than the incredibly popular fang fan duct for me.

This was measured and designed to blow as little air as possible over the heating block, and focuses all the air on the nozzle, pointing in a slightly downward direction, I have used an open flow system as opposed to a directed duct as in tests it showed slightly better results. As it sits very close to the end of the nozzle on my machine, it may sit in a different place on yours and not work ideally, use with your own discretion.

There is a small amount of bridging required, and there are simple, easy to remove supports built into the stl, I have not tried to print this without a fan already in place. The 5015 fan is a push fit and is quite snug, so you may need to shave bits off the mount with a scalpel to get a really good fit.
